so the call is when you go out on the balcony on your tower and you look out

what's important to note here is that these are distinctively different towers

a new climb you have to start over and you have to

and also what it's not so when i talk about leadership i talk about the people that are able to
set out the vision for themselves and visualize what you need to create or where you need to go
it's not about authority it's not about telling people to go somewhere it's about painting that picture of what
could be possible and then evangelizing it so that means going first and helping
others see what you see inspiring them to see what you see to join you on your journey
because leadership is about facilitating a voluntary movement of people in a certain direction it's
not about telling them to follow it's about inspiring them to follow so in contrast leadership is about going
first and pulling people with you not as management which is pushing people telling them to go first
and leadership is also about attitudes and in that you might put stuff like
principles or priorities and what that means is you have to be
the change that you want to see so if you want to see something change you do it you do it first and you show
people how it's done and furthermore leadership that's something you do it's
not something you are and that's tricky for some people to understand is you
don't necessarily need the title of lead or leader
in order to lead because it's an act right it's not a
role or it's not a title and what makes it really tricky is also
leadership is in itself several different skills that go down into psychology and group dynamics and some
type of uh management skills and some type of coaching and there's a bunch of
these different things that are bundled up into this one word so it's actually pretty complex it's not
like going out learning a new programming language which might be very distinct and depending on where you are and who

but one thing that if you look at right now is that it's also one of the most sought after

i didn't want to be on teams that created software that because of poor

and the next thing that happens once you decide to start is you encounter the fear

and there's two types of fear or maybe there's more but there's two types of distinct fear
the one is the fear that you create um
one is the the fear that you create yourself and that's the stuff we sometimes call
self-doubt those are the things we tell ourselves this is going to be hard
i don't know how to do this i will never learn how to do this this is not within my personality to do these types of

to avoid really scary things like in the stone age when we lived in

today that's not really the case but regardless it feels very real and we
start talking ourselves down from the ledge we start talking ourselves down from actually taking the link from
jumping there's a few things you can do if you experience this
one of the best tools that i personally found is visualization and there's two types of visualization there's past
visualization and there's future visualization so the way past visualization works
is you think back to the last time you felt the fear you think back to the last time you had
that doubt and you were standing in front of something really hard then you did it anyway and you succeeded
and you think about that moment and you take that feeling that you have now and you bring it into
the now it to now you think you know if i could do it then i can do it now and you kill
some of those self dots the other type of visualization is future visualization
and that is all about thinking about how it looks when you're there how does it look when you're leading how are you
working how does your work look what are you doing differently how are you you know and all those
things and then when you have that dream picture when you painted that idea
you bring it back to now and you act right because that's the mistake a lot of
people do they do the forward visualization they dream about how it will look when they get there
and then they don't do anything about it so the most important thing is you pick up the next step once you've done that
it's like saying you know i want to lose weight and dreaming about going to the gym or being thin
but it all starts with like picking up your gym clothes and going out the door so that's what i mean about taking the
first step at a second fear is slightly different right
because it comes from others and these are the things other people will tell you
and this might be your peers a lot of people inside especially

you've been great like why why are you looking at this so it might be your peers but it might even be managers

actually earning pretty well you're doing your 40 hour work weeks and

between jobs or whatever and there might be pressure from that that um
that circle of people around you so this is
the best thing you can do about this is to treat all those comments as feedback
and then go learn how to take feedback this is going to be useful for you as a leader
so here's my trick what i do when i get feedback is i treat it as a gift
so you accept the feedback you take it in as a gift you open it up and you do as you do when you get a gift
you say thank you to the person offering you the feedback you say thank you so much for taking the time to tell me this
then you look at the gift and you look what is this exactly and what do i want to do with it
you can choose to take that gift and kind of integrate it into yourself and be like this is a really good gift i
should really wear it as close to my heart and and you know carry it with me or you can think well
it's a kind of okay gift it might be useful you can just take it and put it on a shelf behind you and save it for later and maybe look at it
it might come in handy at some point or and this is completely fine to do with gifts you take and you say like

right and if you're really courageous when you get that feedback you can also be
curious so even somebody says something that you strongly disagree with or that
you find offensive you can start asking questions about that so that's interesting like why
why why are you saying that like what makes you say that and now where did that come from and
not in a in an arguing way never argue about that feedback but in a curious way
to understand the deeper meaning because maybe there's something in there you know maybe there's a real concern that

what i mean about that is the things you do are not who you are

we get a lot of praise for what we do we get a lot of confirmation for what we do

and it's not entirely your fault because that comes from the type of
a confirmation you've been getting the other type of confirmation you can

five-year-old knows they will fail at that task but it doesn't matter because they have so much self-esteem they're like you

if you're feeling these things how do you build that self-esteem in order to be able to drop your developer identity
well there's a few different ways of doing this and here's one which is this is

and however that looks for you you know some might want a coffin someone want to your urine some might want a church and

whatever way that looks for you you visualize that that you just died and and
you're there and people start showing up and then they do speeches so you

like that and people come there and then you imagine what are they saying in their
speech because if you think about funeral speeches those rarely talk about what
people did they always talk about how people were or what they were
right and then you write those things down and now you kind of have a little template about you know this is me and you can
build your self-esteem using that another way is simply going ask going out and asking people
asking your friends or your spouse or even your managers and people your work is like what do you like about me like

the next thing here is also about you but it's about leading yourself
so one thing i sometimes hear is you know i would love to go into leadership but i nobody's asked me or i don't have

yourself this means how are you talking to yourself when you do good things when you succeed what are

leadership i chances are it's not because our inner
voices are pretty mean and they're pretty horrible for most people so you need to deal with that you need

one practice you can do is designate time to improve yourself
set out one hour two hours whatever you can cut out from from uh
from your daily daily routine to uh to work on yourself
you can use techniques that you're familiar familiar with already so if you're in this talk if you're thinking

apply to holding personal retrospectives so you can use that to kind of look at you know
what am i good at where do i need improvement what are things i should start doing what are things i should stop doing
what are the top priorities for next week or the next two weeks that i'm going to be working on
and and kind of do that as a self-improvement project
and the last thing here is about finding your why
and finding your why it can be done in several different different ways and there's a lot of good literature about
that there's simon sinek starting with why there was the business model me book
and there's a bunch of other books talking about you know finding that reason
and what i mean about that reason is there's this story about three people
carrying stones down the road and somebody goes up to them and says to the first person
so uh i see you're carrying stones so so you know what are you doing he says well
it's obvious i'm carrying a stone what do you think as the second person you know so how
about you what are you doing well you know i'm providing for my family and that's the third person's what are you
doing and that person looks at me and says i'm building a cathedral so you need to figure out why you're
doing the things that you're doing and that can't be you know i'm doing them simply because i am doing them
it can't be i'm doing them because you know i need money to pay rent and buy food for my family
it has to be you know what's your cathedral what's your cause why are you doing things that you're doing
that that can take some time and the last thing in the abyss
is about committing to actually doing the investment of going into leadership
because one thing you won't get more of is time we all get the same amount of time same
24 hours so what you can control is where you put your time
what i mean about that is you're going up this entirely new tower
there's a lot of things you need to learn up that tower you have to be okay by not
investing in your old tower by not investing in the technology tower i see a lot of people wanting to go into
leadership and they try to do both and they just simply can't manage because you can't keep up with all the tech
stuff and also learn all these new leadership skills that you need to be learning so
you need to be able to reallocate your resources saying the majority of the time i spend on learning new things
is going to be in this leadership tower and i'm going to be okay with kind of falling behind on the tech stuff
and the reason that is scary because you're going to come to a point where this the tech stuff is kind of
dwindling down and you're kind of you're not keeping up and the leadership stuff isn't really on par
so at that moment in time you're just kind of bad at both
and that's why that is really scary to committing to that investment all right so say we've done this we've
dealt with ourselves we've committed to doing the investment and we're starting to climb
so this is when you start going up that leadership tower you really start being able to use the skills that you have
to lead others you might give me formal informal leadership roles and the number one issue
new leaders run into is the issue of how does work actually look
when i go into my job what is it i'm supposed to be doing
and the reason this trips up a lot of people is because this thing that you've just
went from contributor to catalyst meaning
you went from that the value you provide to your team or your company comes from the things i
actually create and i ship to the value that i create for my team
or my company comes from the way i support and inspire other people to
create things that they should so you go from that individual contributor role to the catalyst the
things that you do don't matter anymore in in sense of of production
what matters is how much better do you make the people around you
and you know there's a few things and the reason this becomes an issue for
a lot of people is because they really try to do both a lot of new leaders they go in and they think
you know i'm not only supposed to be the inspiring person that goes first and
sets up sets all the visions and does all the things and supports my team i'm also supposed to be the best
contributor on my team because that that's that's what i'm supposed to do i'm supposed to write the best code and shift most code and do
most code do most features and everything and they go into overdrive
work late hours and eventually burn out so you need to be okay with finding
yourself in a catalyst role and because you won't be up to par on the tech and chances are if you're done
leadership correctly a lot of people on your team are currently better at the technology than you are
so what does this mean well it means for me the trick i did because i went
into this spiral i tried to be all those things the trick that i did when i noticed this
was i kind of made a deal with myself there will not be a single commit inner git repository
with my name on it that doesn't mean i don't work on code that doesn't mean
i i don't help out it just means i don't own those things because if i can't commit code i can't
pull stories on the ken button board or scrum board or whatever either so now
i have to wait for somebody else to pick something up and i could go to them and be like hey can i work with you on this
or do you want a pair program or do you need help on this and we can work on that together because
then if i need to take care of something i'm not owning that feature i'm not owning that code somebody else's
this was a great thing for my team because this is the first time i really saw my team rise to the location
of taking being empowered and taking accountability for what they should
the second thing i've seen and this is for people that maybe are architects or have an architect role they usually do
this is that they decided you know i'm going to build a framework i'm going to be like the core of the application i'm
just going to have my team like build stuff around that that's also a really bad mistake
that code and that core that's going to burn and it's going to burn when you least
have time to fix it and nobody else is going to know how it works and nobody else is going to dare
to open it up and mess with it and you're going to be busy doing other things so it's going to end up being you
on evenings and weekends trying to fix that stuff because right now you're blocking your team you're not really
leading them so you really need to get out of that production mindset
and shift to making sure that you're a catalyst for your
team and next thing is the idea that you're supposed to adapt to others
since doing leadership is a lot of introspection it's a lot about thinking about yourself and your own things when
you start leading others you need to understand that in your role as a leader also is the responsibility to meet
people where they where where they are and pick them up where they are
and this means making sure that you understand that everybody is unique everybody has unique strengths everybody
has a unique personality there's these different people and there's not one way
of talking to or being with those people and they need different things from you
as a leader and it's your responsibility to make sure you can provide that so one thing for instance is
never take out an introvert to a cafe or a lunch
for a serious talk right so if you have a one-on-one and most introverts prefer
doing that in like a calm office setting somewhere away from people and while extroverts might be really cool with
going out to cafes or on a lunch and having their one-on-ones and and same thing you know if you know
some extroverts really prefer like a phone call for check-in or a face-to-face meeting well you might want
to you know send a slack message to some some people on your team and this is not just about introverts and extroverts i'm
using that as an example uh all people have these different abilities and want
to be approached differently so it's about reading the person and figuring out what works for this person
and then meeting them where they are picking them up where they are and this also comes down to this idea
here that you know about situational leadership so this this model of situational
leadership it's about using two different leadership styles it's about using the directive leadership style and
then there's the supportive leadership style and the difference is the directive is
more about you know hey i think you should be doing this and the supportive
is more about you know so what do you think and my biggest mistake was
i came from agile leadership so i was doing the supportive leadership style
100 of the time and i was working really well with senior
people or people that have worked for a while and have some skill but i was miserably failing with people that were
juniors i was like what am i doing wrong and then somebody showed me this and
said you know depending on your skill level motivation and skill the motivational skill will
vary so when you're starting out and you're very new to something you have really high motivation but you also have
really low skill so those people you need to help them and give them direction
to show them where they should put their energy be like hey i want you to really work on this i want you to really do
